text: Lucy Joan Slater (5 January 1922 ‚Äì 6 June 2008) was a British mathematician who studied mathematical functions. Many mathematical identities have been named after her.Andrews, G. E., Knopfmacher, A., Paule, P., & Prodinger, H. (2001). q-Engel series expansions and Slater's identities. Quaestiones Mathematicae, 24(3), 403-416.Hikami, K., & Kirillov, A. (2006). Hypergeometric generating function of ùêø-function, Slater‚Äôs identities, and quantum invariant. St. Petersburg Mathematical Journal, 17(1), 143-156. For example, there is the Jackson-Slater identityWeisstein, Eric W. "Jackson-Slater Identity." From MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource. http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Jackson- SlaterIdentity.html and the Rogers-Ramanujan-Slater identity.Mc Laughlin, J., Sills, A. V., & Zimmer, P. (2008). Rogers-Ramanujan-Slater Type Identities. the electronic journal of combinatorics, 1000, 15-31.Sills, A. V. (2007). Identities of the Rogers‚ÄìRamanujan‚ÄìSlater type. International Journal of Number Theory, 3(02), 293-323.McLaughlin, J., & Sills, A. V. (2008). Ramanujan‚ÄìSlater type identities related to the moduli 18 and 24. Journal of Mathematical Analysis and Applications, 344(2), 765-777.McLaughlin, J., & Sills, A. V. (2008). Combinatorics of Ramanujan-Slater type identities. In Combinatorial Number Theory: Proceedings of the Integers Conference 2007' (p. 125). She is also known for her books about special functionsSlater, Lucy Joan (1960), Confluent hypergeometric functions, Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press.Slater, Lucy Joan (1966), Generalized hypergeometric functions, Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press. and Fortran.Fortran programs for economists, Cambridge University Press, 1967First steps in basic Fortran, London: Chapman & Hall, 1971More Fortran programs for economists, Cambridge University Press, 1972 ==Related pages== * Timeline of women in mathematics ==References== ==Other websites== * * category:1922 births category:2008 deaths category:British mathematicians
